data.title: Latest dev builds: first performance drop, now NoSuitableGraphicsDeviceException?
data.body:
I am running MonoGame on Windows with Visual Studio 2015 Community.  I recently ported an XNA project that utilizes 3D graphics.  Under XNA it was using the HiDef profile.

Using MonoGame 3.5.1 the performance was indistinguishable from XNA, but there was a bug using the Xbox One controller.  If it was plugged in when the game was launched, it didn't work until it was unplugged, then reconnected.

I decided to try using the latest dev build to see if that bug was fixed.  I grabbed it as of a few weeks ago, version 3.6.0.1365.  At first, it didn't run at all...there were some minor changes I had to make, but the biggest issue was an error telling me I had to use 16-bit indices rather than 32-bit indices.  Huh?  I ultimately realized that it was trying to force the Reach profile, and fixed it by adding the following line in my constructor:

graphics.GraphicsProfile = GraphicsProfile.HiDef;

where "graphics" is my GraphicsDeviceManager.  This got the game running, and the controller detection bug had indeed been fixed in the new MonoGame build, but the framerate was approximately half of what it had been before.  The game looked identical, but the performance had dropped like a rock.

I was hoping that this was just a temporary bug.  I tried again with version 3.6.0.1425 just a few days ago (which is still the current version as of 1/29/2017).  But now the game won't start at all.  It builds OK, but crashes during initialization with a Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.NoSuitableGraphicsDeviceException.

I am using a 2010 MacBook sporting an integrated GeForce 320M GPU.  Yeah, an antique by today's standards, but it always ran my XNA stuff quite easily.  

Were the hardware requirements just raised?  If so, why?  If not, what could be causing this?

If there's no easy fix for this (and the performance issues), is it possible for me to Frankenstein the new Input code into MonoGame 3.5.1 and use that instead, for its superior performance?

Thanks very much for your assistance.

data.title: Prevent crash when multisampling is not supported in DirectX
data.body:
If the GPU/driver does not support multisampling for a back buffer format, the quality returned is 0, which became -1.  Passing this value to create the D3D11Device causes it to fail with a SharpDX exception.

Don't know how to add a unit test for this since it appears to be hardware/driver dependent.

data.title: DesktopGL was not using back buffer and depth buffer formats
data.body:
OpenGL was being initialized with default OpenGL formats, which does not include a stencil buffer.  SDL2 requires the SDL GL attributes to be set before the window is created.  The window creation has been delayed to just prior to the graphics device being created and the setting of the SDL GL attributes was moved earlier to just prior to the window being created.  Unit tests were added for stencil clip.

Fixes #5441

data.title: XAudio: Fixed output channel levels to match XNA
data.body:
There are currently a few issues relating to sound effect output channel levels in MonoGame. e.g.

- Stereo samples sometimes only playing on the left speaker
- Levels being too loud when panning is applied
- Levels being too loud when more than 2 output speakers are configured (e.g. 5.1/7.1 Surround)

This PR fixes these issues, and makes the output channel levels in line with XNA (see issue #5054 for further details).

I've also added some XAudio specific unit tests which confirm that the output matrix calculations are returning expected results.

Fixes #5054

data.title: Simplified parameter prefix
data.body:
Replaces #5421.

* Added "-" as an optional parameter prefix in addition to "/" in 2MGFX.
* Source file and output file parameters in 2MGFX now use "/SourceFile:" and "/OutputFile:" parameter names to avoid trying to differentiate between parameters and absolute paths on Linux and Mac.

data.title: SharpDX 3.x.x update
data.body:
**UPD. The information below is wrong - the performance boost was not from SharpDX improvement but from switching MonoGame to RELEASE build from DEBUG.**


I've updated SharpDX to 3.1.0 and got about 300-400% better framerate in our game. Sweet!
Perhaps the improvement is so dramatic because there are a lot of drawcalls (it's too early to optimize this in our game yet).

I was needed to fix a few places in master branch of MonoGame for proper compatibility with it, also SharpDX.Mathematics.dll should be references now as it was separated from the SharpDL.dll.

There are a few drawbacks: starting from 3.0.0 SharpDX requires .NET 4.5. And a problem with MGFX - it seems when SharpDX 3.1.0 is used it tries to compile with D3DCompiler_47.dll which is available (and works) only at Windows 8.1/10 SDK, so Windows 7 is not supported. Perhaps we need to ask at SharpDX repository about this requirement as I didn't found anything related to this.

Regards!

data.title: Split MGCB into lib and CLI
data.body:
Feature request! Or rather proposal because I'd implement this myself if this is accepted.

I'd like to split MGCB into a DLL and a CLI so users can easily use the lib in whatever they like to build on top of the MG build system. The Pipeline Tool could also use that rather than calling the MGCB executable, that would be much nicer IMO. We could call the class library MGCBlib and the CLI just MGCB so we don't actually change the name.

I got this idea when looking at the code a bit to check out issues @UncleThomy ran into. http://community.monogame.net/t/typical-working-command-line-inputs-for-mgcb/8655/3
That also revealed that the '/define' option is not actually implemented. I'd also generally like to make the CLI a bit more robust and smarter e.g. by allowing spaces in options (and trimming them). 

üëç or üëé?

data.title: misc xact fixes from ps4
Fix unit test report missing some tests
data.body:
As mentioned in #5428, the HTML report generated by the test runner missed test classes that had both successful and ignored tests, but no failures.

The problem was that the XSL transform first displayed failed and then succeeded tests. However, the template for succeeded tests only ran when there were no failed *or ignored* tests. No path handled the successful+ignored case. There was no need at all for the two code paths, since the original code also sorted the test cases based on the outcome.

Also removed some files which seem to have existed for testing the XSL template back in 2012.

data.title: SpriteBatch with simple colored quad
data.body:
One of the big frustrations I have over and over again is that I need to provide a texture input for SpriteBatch.Draw() even if I just want a colored quad to be drawn.

I think almost everyone who worked with Mono or XNA can relate to this problem and creating a white 1x1 texture everytime is bothersome, and needless to say it's useless GPU overhead to need a texture read for every pixel.

At the same time spritebatch is super accessible, especially for beginners, and probably a better implementation of quad batching than most are willing to implement themselves.

I would therefore propose an implementation of a draw function with only 
`(Rectangle destinationRectangle, Color color)`
inputs, with a simplified pixel shader along the lines of
```
PixelShader(...)
{
return input.Color;
}
```

Of course a different overload with stuff like SpriteEffects, Rotation etc. could also be provided.

Alternatively it could be called DrawColor or DrawQuad to make it distinct from the normal Draw();

What do you think?

EDIT: I haven't thought about the batching actually, i just thought about convenience. But it obviously can't work with the batching. I still think it would be nice to provide a function to draw colored quads by default, even if not with the default spritebatch.
Or have a 1x1 texture provided internally so this function can be done.

I applied the #5426 fix for the compressed texture regression, so those failures are omitted. That regression would have been caught if the tests were runnable.

These issues are still open or should be investigated:

data.title: Fix two bugs in OpenAL implementation
data.body:
* An oversight by me caused `Stop()` to be executed on an already disposed sound effect, which is a throwing operation with `DynamicSoundEffectInstance` (XNA compatibility).
* The native DLL search path was set in `SDLGamePlatform` constructor, but the audio tests are run first. Therefore `soft_oal.dll` was not found, which caused test failures and an epic finalizer crash, rendering the test project unrunnable as is. I added the path check to `OpenALSoundController` so that there is no load order dependency anymore.

data.title: Command-line parameter prefixes
data.body:
Command-line parameters on Windows use /
Command-line parameters on Linux and Mac use - for short parameters and -- for long parameters.

Started this because - and -- is what non-Windows users expect, and 2MGFX fails to parse parameters on non-Windows platforms with absolute paths (starting with /) as the input or output parameters.

data.title: Persist GraphicsDevice across tests and limit frame size for visual tests
data.body:
This PR greatly improves unit testing performance for graphics tests. Local graphics testing time went from ~37 seconds to ~7.

Here are the local run times in this branch as reported by ReSharpers unit test runner:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14875382/21983857/834ca88e-dbf3-11e6-94dd-e212873949aa.png)

The stuff that still takes long is:

1. Audio conversion tests take about 7 seconds. We can probably cut down on the used audio duration a bit if we want to improve here. There are 3 audio files used, one of about 1 second and the other two of 7 seconds.
2. Compiling the stock effects takes about 10 seconds. Not sure if it's D3DCompiler or our code, this could be looked at for better performance.
3. IntermediateDeserializer takes some time because of IO I guess. Not much to do here.
4. The framework tests take over 3 seconds because of 1 leftover test that actually creates a window and runs a game. If not for that the Framework tests would take less than a second.
5. Some Graphics test still need to create a new device or reset the existing one (in GraphicsDeviceTest and GraphicsDeviceManagerTest), that takes a bit of time but is required for proper testing. One thing we could do to speed up graphics tests is run the frame comparison in parallel (not across tests, but for a single test or even a single frame). It shouldn't be too hard to try that out, so I might give that a shot.
6. There's one other test under Visual/Misc that creates a window and runs a game. I have a plan for adding a setting to run MG headless in Game if that's acceptable. That would fix this and 4. and will allow for testing Game more easily in the future. Could also be nice for users (http://community.monogame.net/t/headless-monogame/7063).
7. DynamicSoundEffectInstance does some sleeping to wait for soundeffects to finish/progress. it looks like this can be cut down on a little bit by reducing soundeffect duration.

So there's still some optimization that can be done probably.

While persisting the GraphicsDevice across tests gives a significant performance boost there is a small downside too. There is no way to reset the bound shaders and constantbuffers through the api. Tests that depend on shaders not being bound will need to call HardReset first. That disposes the current device and creates a new one. For other tests a SoftReset (called automatically) seems to suffice. I made the GraphicsDeviceSetUpFixture flag a device reset so it knows to do a hard reset after the test so no big changes are persisted (like changing the GraphicsProfile). 

We're not using 'fresh' GraphicsDevice every test in this branch, but everything is reset properly so I don't think there are risks of mistesting with these changes.
